title: How to Monitor Your Competitors
description: Stay ahead by tracking what customers say about competitors and finding opportunities they miss.
requirements: 15 minutes per month for ongoing monitoring

steps.title: Identify your main competitors
substeps: Search Google for '[your service] near me'
Note the top 5 businesses that show up
Include any competitors customers mention to you
Look at who's advertising on Google and Facebook
steps.tip: Focus on competitors in your service area, not big national companies.

steps.title: Set up Google Alerts
steps.description: Get notified when competitors are mentioned online.
substeps: Go to google.com/alerts
Create an alert for each competitor's business name
Choose 'As-it-happens' or 'Once a day' delivery
Add alerts for your own business name too

steps.title: Analyze their Google reviews
steps.description: Learn from what customers say about them.
substeps: Search '[Competitor Name] reviews' on Google
Read their recent Google reviews
Note what customers praise (do you do this too?)
Note complaints (can you solve these better?)
steps.tip: Competitor complaints are your opportunities. If people complain about wait times, emphasize your fast response.

steps.title: Check their Google Business Profile
steps.description: See what services and offers they're promoting.
substeps: Look at their GBP listing
Note: Services listed, prices shown, recent posts
What photos do they use?
Are they running any promotions?

steps.title: Follow their social media
substeps: Find them on Facebook, Instagram, Nextdoor
Follow or bookmark their pages
Note: How often do they post? What content works?
What are people saying in the comments?

steps.title: Do a monthly competitive review
substeps: Once a month, spend 15 minutes reviewing
Check their latest reviews (any patterns?)
Note any new services or promotions
Ask yourself: What can I learn from this?

successMessage: You now have a system to track competitors! Use these insights to differentiate yourself.
proTips: Don't copy competitors â€” look for gaps they're leaving
Negative reviews of competitors tell you what customers value most
If a competitor closes or struggles, reach out to their customers
